awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   CI-SUSTAIN: National File System Trace Repository
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will sustain and enhance a national repository of traces that capture usage of file-systems, storage and input/outputs with the goal of helping researchers to address performance bottlenecks. As part of ongoing activities, new tools essential to the successful use of traces will be added. Also, new mirror sites are planned to expand efficiency and utility of the trace repository. The national repository of file systems traces is of immense importance to the software engineering community. By updating the traces for the new and emerging applications, this project provides a vital service to this community.

Disk based file system is a performance bottleneck for many computer applications. Thus, it is useful to have a set of activity traces for storage systems to understand the access characteristics. Such traces may potentially help optimize flash-based solid-state storage and other emerging non-volatile memory based storage technologies. As the storage technologies evolve with network storage, cloud-based storage, Geo-replicated storage, the trace repository provides a set of targets for storage systems optimization.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Computer systems are fairly complex to understand and optimize.  The
data storage components (such a disks and "file systems") are the
slowest components of computer systems, and hence the best part to
analyze and optimize first.  Proper analysis and optimizations require
reproducible experiments and high quality, diverse data sets.

A time-honored technique is to collect event information from
computers' data-storage systems.  These event records are also called
"traces."  However, storage traces are hard to come by, can be fairly
large and difficult to disseminate, and can be challenging to release
due to privacy concerns (e.g., they may contain information about
users' activity).  Past traces have also failed to describe the format
of the data trace and the conditions under which it was taken.
Finally, there was a lack of software for collecting, analyzing,
processing, and replaying storage traces.

This project enhanced and extended the Storage Networking Industry
Association (SNIA) Trace Repository, which was originally created
using prior NSF grants.  As part of this project, we established
mirrors of the original site, located on both coasts of the U.S. and
in the Far East, guaranteeing fast service to users and robustness
against disasters.  We acquired multiple terabytes of traces and
released them to the community.  The project also improved and
released software based on the DataSeries storage trace format
package.  The project released tools to capture traces efficiently
from applications and even from inside the computer operating system
(e.g., Linux).  The traces were processed into a uniform format using
DataSeries.  Tools to analyze, extract statistics, and replay the
traces were developed and released.  All such artifacts (code and
data) were released via the Storage Networking Industry Association
(SNIA) Web site (iotta.snia.org).

To date, traces hosted at the repository have been downloaded many
thousands of times.  Hundreds of publications citing the traces were
published during the project's period.  Given the history of extensive
trace usage in the storage community and the planned continued
operation of the site, we expect the project's impact to continue for
several decades to come.


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Geoff Kuenning
